etymologies: Old English hlot (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch lot, German Los. The original meanings were lot (sense 3 of the noun) and (by extension) the sense ‘a portion assigned to someone’; the latter gave rise to the other noun senses. The pronoun and adverb uses date from the early 19th century

notes.text: The expressions a lot of and lots of are used before nouns to mean “a large number or amount of”. In common with other words denoting quantities, lot itself does not normally function as a head noun, meaning that it does not itself determine whether the following verb is singular or plural. Thus, although lot is singular in a lot of people, the verb that follows is not singular. In this case the word people acts as the head noun and, being plural, ensures that the following verb is also plural: a lot of people were assembled (not a lot of people was assembled). See also number. Note that alot written as one word is incorrect, although not uncommon

definitions: a large number or amount; a great deal

examples.text: there are a lot of actors in the cast
they took a lot of abuse
a lot can happen in eight months
we had lots of fun

definitions: the whole number or quantity that is involved or implied

examples.text: you might as well take the whole lot
this is probably the most famous of the lot
you're equally likely to lose the lot as well

notes.text: The expressions a lot of and lots of are used before nouns to mean “a large number or amount of”. In common with other words denoting quantities, lot itself does not normally function as a head noun, meaning that it does not itself determine whether the following verb is singular or plural. Thus, although lot is singular in a lot of people, the verb that follows is not singular. In this case the word people acts as the head noun and, being plural, ensures that the following verb is also plural: a lot of people were assembled (not a lot of people was assembled). See also number. Note that alot written as one word is incorrect, although not uncommon

examples.text: he played tennis a lot last year
thanks a lot
my life is lots better now
I feel a whole lot better

notes.text: The expressions a lot of and lots of are used before nouns to mean “a large number or amount of”. In common with other words denoting quantities, lot itself does not normally function as a head noun, meaning that it does not itself determine whether the following verb is singular or plural. Thus, although lot is singular in a lot of people, the verb that follows is not singular. In this case the word people acts as the head noun and, being plural, ensures that the following verb is also plural: a lot of people were assembled (not a lot of people was assembled). See also number. Note that alot written as one word is incorrect, although not uncommon

definitions: a particular group, collection, or set of people or things

examples.text: it's just one lot of rich people stealing from another

definitions: a group or a person of a particular kind (generally used in a derogatory or dismissive way)

examples.text: an inefficient lot, our town council
he was known as a bad lot
you lot think you're clever, don't you?

definitions: an article or set of articles for sale at an auction

examples.text: nineteen lots failed to sell
the picture is lot 16

definitions: one of a set of objects such as straws, stones, or pieces of paper that are randomly selected as part of a decision-making process

examples.text: they drew lots to determine the order in which they asked questions

shortDefinitions: one of set of objects such as straws

definitions: the making of a decision by random selection

examples.text: officers were elected rather than selected by lot

shortDefinitions: making of decision by random selection

definitions: the choice resulting from a decision made by random selection

examples.text: eventually the lot fell on the King's daughter

shortDefinitions: choice resulting from deciding by lot

synonyms.text: decide on the toss of a coin
decide on the throw of a die
decide on the drawing of straws

definitions: a person's luck or condition in life, particularly as determined by fate or destiny

examples.text: plans to improve the lot of the disadvantaged

definitions: a plot of land assigned for sale or for a particular use

examples.text: a vacant lot
a fenced-off back lot

definitions: an area of land near a television or movie studio where outside filming may be done.
the area at a car dealership where cars for sale are kept.

notes.text: The expressions a lot of and lots of are used before nouns to mean “a large number or amount of”. In common with other words denoting quantities, lot itself does not normally function as a head noun, meaning that it does not itself determine whether the following verb is singular or plural. In this case the word people acts as the head noun and, being plural, ensures that the following verb is also plural: a lot of people were assembled (not a lot of people was assembled). See also number. Note that alot written as one word is incorrect, although not uncommon

definitions: divide (items) into lots for sale at an auction

examples.text: the contents have already been lotted up, and the auction takes place on Monday

shortDefinitions: divide items into lots for auction
